pros: Unlimited free drinks before, after, and during shift, employee discount (50%), tuition reimbursement, generous benefits, met and worked with some great people, easy to transfer stores between cities.
cons: Long, exhausting, inflexible hours and poor work/life balance. I was a Supervisor who opened the store five days a week and had to be there for 4 AM - all while I was a full-time University student. I was continuously made to feel like I could never take days off or call in sick because "the store would not open if I was not there". There is very little room for career growth with this company. I met some of the most horrible leaders during my four years with Starbucks. Sure, every company has rotten eggs, but I encountered multiple leaders that would bully and punish staff that they simply didn't like. Starbucks does not live up to their mission and values and try to sweep mistreatment of staff under the rug. Customers could also be absolutely brutal, so that doesn't help either.

pros: -Free drinks and food every shift (my store was very lax about this policy, and we could more or less mark out whatever we wanted within reason) and a free pound of coffee every week. -Competitive wages, regular raises, plus tips for non-salaried employees. -Great medical coverage, even for part-time employees. -Employees (partners) are eligible for company stocks (read: free money). -Mental health is a priority, 20 free Lyra sessions per year starting the day you put on your green apron. -Free Spotify & Headspace premium -Flexible scheduling, generally understanding management. Opportunity for growth and development. Management typically goes out of their way to do the right thing. -Inclusive environment, company goes out of its way to celebrate, hire, and promote BIPOC, LGBTQ+ members, and disabled folks. -Unbelievable opportunity for growth and development. The company even has a “Partner Development Program” to assist with this. -Usually pretty great coworkers, a sense of camaraderie, and ample opportunity to make genuine, lifelong friendships. You’ll also get to know lots of regulars, hear their stories, and make genuine connections every day. -Perfect place to work if you love coffee and want to learn more about the world of coffee.
cons: -Hours can be very varied (extremely early mornings and late nights are part of the culture). Ask any tenured partner to give you a “clopen” horror story to understand this better. -Company culture will absolutely always back up higher management. I have seen issues of harassment, racism, and bullying go unreported and unresolved, because the offending party was a tenured, well liked partner. Favoritism absolutely runs rampant at pretty much every store I’ve ever worked at (8 stores in three different states). -While the job duties themselves are easy on the whole, there is a lot of repetitive movement. Standing in place for eight hours, making the exact same motion to make beverages left me with permanent wrist damage after my time at Starbucks. While the company itself has pretty rigid policies related to this, they aren’t really followed at a store level that I have ever seen. -Can be a dangerous work environment. Due to the early mornings and late nights, I had to call the police for altercations many times (2 of which involved a customer being violent, once involving a firearm). At the very least, it’s stressful- people get very angry about coffee. -Can be a pretentious/socially stressful work environment. I have seen (new partners especially) try to intentionally sabotage coworkers for literally no reason. Especially if you’re over the age of about 25, be warned: this company hires a LOT of teenagers, and there will be drama in any Starbucks store that you set foot in. In some cases, it can be extremely traumatizing. -Work expectations can be a bit high, especially if you’re a closer, and especially if you don’t have a rigid plan that you stick to. -If you don’t advocate for yourself, there’s a risk you’ll get stuck with repetitive shifts no one wants (ie closing five nights a week).

pros: I worked at two stores over my time and they each were wildly different. My first store was a heavenly experience; great management, regular hours, nice discount and deals. I appreciated how I always had the same length shift and a long break. These things are attainable at Starbucks if you get into the right store.
cons: The second store I worked at was horrible, I'm not usually a quitter but I left after four shifts. Hours were way too long with stupidly short break (10 hr shift with 30 min break?). The store was disgusting, no one was able to keep it clean because we were so understaffed and overworked. We were doing in-store, 3 types of delivery services, and mobile orders with only three staff members and a ting workplace. Management continually berated us for not upholding standards but would not change the structure of staffing or shifts so we could adequately do these. Absolute madness all for just above minimum wage.

cons: Management has gone downhill over the years. I worked there between 2016-2022 and we went from a neighbourhood coffee shop to a fast food nightmare. Starbucks makes crazy money but insists on running their stores with a skeleton crew constantly leading to burnout and dissatisfaction. They gave baristas and supervisors several raises recently but have not given the store managers any raises so my old manager was making less /hour than a tenured shift supervisor. Starbucks has great mental health benefits which you will definitely need to take advantage of after working there. They're alss union-busting, very shameful.

review_title: Constant and purposeful short staffing, unfair labor practices
pros: Working at Starbucks made me a really good worker as there is so much work to be done everyday, once you learn the routines the job makes a lot of sense and it can feel satisfying once you understand how everything works, you will probably bond with your fellow baristas a lot as you will go through so much together, I learned a lot about the importance and beauty of team work here
cons: They constantly short staff every single day, they constantly cut hours, you will never get full time unless you become a store manager but most store managers are outside hires who have never been a barista before, they never make you feel as if you’re doing a good job they’re always telling you you’re never doing enough, they will work you into the ground, you will not be compensated for how much hard work you actually are doing, there is zero focus on coffee or the quality of beverages you are serving- you won’t learn anything about coffee because there is no time, they cut hours because they do not want you spending time together or else you might start discussing the unfair labor practices and how bad you are being treated, corporate (the ones who are being paid thousands and thousands more than you and don’t even know a single drink recipe) will never listen to you about your needs or your concerns- they will thank you for bringing it to them, promise that they are going to put in the work to change whatever you’re concerned about, and make you feel really good about what you brought up, and then do absolutely nothing and hope you just forget about the entire thing which you probably will because you have to get back to work, they claim the customer connection is the most important aspect of your work but only give you literally 40 seconds to take payment and get the drinks made and out the window and to the customer, then they will blame you when you have a bad customer connection score, there is no reward for staying with company for a long time in fact they want the high turnover they have so that, again, you cannot start thinking about how bad you’re being treated as an employee

pros: They work well with your schedule, I've heard the benefits are good, they're typically pretty inclusive as far as hiring goes.
cons: There's no real work/life balance that can be had without management and corporate shaming you. There's no way to defend yourself throughout consistent and constant verbal abuse from customers. Though it seems on the surface to be progressive, they're very conservative in their ideals. They're also aggressively anti-union and do not allow the 'partners' a safe space to speak out on their needs. They're very uninvolved with harassment in their own stores, and often let these people continue to stay employed despite cases being made against them. They prioritize the needs of customers over that of their employees to a concerning degree and disregard safety over profit. It's hard to advance within the company, but our manager played hard favorites as well. Management at my specific store would pit partners against each other when they actually raised grievances with his behavior to take the heat off of him. He was often absent and unavailable after 2-3 pm. He was irresponsible, and often hostile whenever late afternoon/evening crew reached out on matters that genuinely required his input. There was little to no communication to be had, and he'd often take unannounced vacations. Not to mention he committed microaggressions against many queer, bipoc, and disabled members of our staff. He was often sexist and tried to have inappropriate relations with younger (though of legal age) partners.

pros:
Flexible schedule and employee benefits as a part timer make this an excellent way to earn money and have affordable healthcare while going to school or taking care of kids

Their partnership with ASU makes getting an education feasible for partners 

Some stores have unionized

Training was understandable and followup training kept even long time baristas up to date with what they should be doing for the store and how
cons:
You don't actually learn much about traditional coffee (which is really only a problem if you find you love coffee and want to move to a more local/professional coffeeshop)

High volume stores feel more like an assembly line

Drive thru is the worst and most Starbucks are now drive thru inclusive with cafe only stores being closed

Licensed stores (starbucks you find in Kroger's or Barnes and noble) are not considered true Starbucks and baristas there are not afforded the same training and benefits as full store Starbucks baristas

pros: In theory, there are benefits if you jump through the hoops and read all the fine print and meet all the hidden criteria to access them.
cons: The company is organized for maximum exploitation of employees. I was paid exactly one penny above the legal minimum wage. Management is explicitly ordered to schedule an insufficient amount of staff so that the few staff doing many jobs are forced to exert themselves to maximum capacity, leaving them vulnerable to verbal and sometimes physical threats and assaults by angry customers, frustrated by staff incapable of doing more than what is possible. The majority of my coworkers developed workplace-caused long-term injuries that negatively affected their day-to-day life outside of work, often requiring them to wear braces at all times on their wrists (from making drinks) or knees/ankles (from being on their feet all day constantly moving).

pros: Starbucks offers decent pay, tips and benefits compared to similar companies. You receive a free pound of coffee once per week, stock in the company after two years, and free beverages and food items while working.
cons: This is an extremely stressful job, but that's entirely dependent on location and the store manager that you have. In my personal experience, most store managers are not very competent and when you combine that lack of support from your superiors with the amount of stress and menial pay, this is not for everyone and definitely could use a pay bump. In addition, hours allotted for each store are dependent on sales from previous weeks, which more often than not means that the store is understaffed and you are doing the job of three people. Not fun.

pros:
If you take advantage of the benefits (medical insurance, free Spotify, free online college, etc) it’s great!
Depending on the store, there’s usually a great family atmosphere between the partners (because we’re all trauma bonded)
Free drinks, getting to experiment
The most extensive dress code while still letting you express yourself (again enforcing is dependent on your store management, some do the older, stricter dress code I’ve heard)
-shift pay is amazing now
cons:
-The customers are ridiculous. Half the time they’re straight up mean and use the prices as justification to not treat us as humans who can and will make mistakes but we’ll also fix said mistakes.
-The management at my store is awesome, but I know just like any other fast food chain, management can be vastly different store to store and has been known to play favorites or hire externally instead of promoting within.
- if you are a barista, the job is stressful but can be fun. If you become a shift… most I know have a second job that pays less just to get away from the siren for a bit.
-the business model is a mess, they allow more sales to come in than we can manage and blame us when we can’t keep up. There will be a time when 15 mobile orders came in at the same time and you still have to take care of the people who came in through the front does and the drive thru with bare bones staff. 
-when you start training, expect to cry. Everyone I know working here, both at my store and others have said they went home crying the first few weeks/months. It’s rough.

review_title: Great Company, Needs Better Training System
pros:
-- Pays 100% tuition for your first bachelor's degree at ASU online. Amazing program. 

-- Great benefits for a food service job. Free Spotify premium, free Headspace premium, free therapy sessions (like 20 sessions a year or half year or something)

-- A whole platform to receive discounts on things like travel, cars, technology, and more.
cons: The process of becoming a Barista Trainer need to be redesigned. Many Barista Trainers at my store have told me they didn't know what to talk about and teach their trainees, and it shows when these trainees get out onto the floor and aren't able to do simple things like brew a fresh batch of coffee, process a refund, ring up a gift card, or take orders. This trickles into people who have been there for longer having to do more work because half the people on the floor are new and not trained well enough. I don't think this is the trainer or trainee's fault necessarily, just that Starbucks needs to provide better training material for Barista Trainers to train new people who can confidently step onto the floor ready to go.

job_title: Senior Concept Designer in London, England
pros: Strong company culture, an overall nurturing environment and friendly peers. Emphasis on partner wellbeing and flexibility, but also purposeful and achievement driven. Being self-initiated and bringing ideas to the table is highly valued, which makes the work feel meaningful.
cons: There can be small furstrations like with any other job, but it really doesn't defy the everyday experience.

pros: Decent pay Flexible scheduling If you hire and develop the right team you'll have a great day to day experience
cons: Work/life balance (personal phone always on, must cover call outs, must have another SM cover you for vacation/must cover other managers for their vacations) District manager is responsible for creating the culture and experience for SMs. I've had really great DMs and horrible DMs. Current DM is never in stores, complains a lot and makes comments that are grossly inappropriate. For the first time in my career I'm actually incredibly disappointed in the person I'm supposed to look to as my "leader." In 10 months my DM has been in my store 4 times total while I'm expected to be there minimally 5 days per week. I know the DM is overseeing multiple stores but within a full working year I'd expect that they could make it in to see me & the team more than 4 times. Little to no growth opportunities beyond SM role. Most upper leadership positions are externally hired and then most corporate positions require you to be a DM first. It leaves you feeling unappreciated and in a dead end job as a SM. DM will promise to prioritize your development but not do anything. You have to give 150% while everyone else can give less. I haven't had a PPV in years. PDC has moved to Teams and rarely do we ever discuss my development just store performance. Never had a rewards conversation this year. The company is just different. They'll claim to be politically neutral but I think we all know the company is left leaning. If you don't align politically it can be a frustrating place to work. People constantly posting their political opinions on Workplace. Field leaders making political jokes assuming all partners are liberal. The company cares more about introducing each other with pronouns than they do ACTUAL dignity & respect. It's just an odd time to work here. Constant cuts at the bottom level. It's to be expected to protect the P&L but we are always cutting labor, running out of product, making SMs manage two stores. The list goes on and on. It's truthfully embarrassing and not at all reflective of the company I joined years ago.
